article.description:
Bryant Markson scored 24 points and pulled down eight rebounds while
leading the Utes to a 64-49 victory over New Mexico on Wednesday in
a rematch of last season's Mountain West Conference championship
game.
article.headline: Markson powers Utah in win over New Mexico
article.linkText: Markson powers Utah in win over New Mexico
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Bryant Markson got a little revenge for two of Utah's few losses last season. Markson scored 24 points and pulled down eight rebounds while leading the Utes to a 64-49 victory over New Mexico on Wednesday in a rematch of last season's Mountain West Conference championship game. The Lobos had upset the top-seeded Utes in the MWC tournament and also beat Utah late in the regular season, but didn't come close Wednesday. "We feel like we're a top team in the Mountain West Conference and we're trying to prove that right now," Markson said. Johnnie Bryant added 13 points and Utah (8-4, 1-0 MWC) outrebounded New Mexico (9-5, 0-1) by a 38-27 margin and kept the Lobos winless in five games on the road this season. Mark Walters scored 19 and David Chiotti added eight of his 13 points in the second half for the Lobos, who were just 16-for-49 from the field and never recovered after Utah started the second half with a 16-6 run. "I thought that the beginning of the second half is where we lost the game," New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay said. It was just the second time in his career that Markson reached 20 points. He didn't need to score much as a junior last season, playing next to Andrew Bogut, but this season Utah coach Ray Giacoletti is depending on Markson -- one of only four seniors on the team. The Lobos let Markson shoot from the outside and he made his first three 3-pointers. "You've got to worry a little bit. I mean, I can score if I get hot. It was one of those good nights and everything was going for me," Markson said. Markson topped his previous high of 20 points, scored against Colorado State last January. Markson got a loud round of applause when he left in the final minute despite the small crowd that showed up on the night of college football's national championship game. The home team has won the last seven regular-season meetings between the Utes and Lobos and it was quickly apparent in the second half that the streak was going to continue. "We've got to have the mindset of being the aggressive," Giacoletti said. "With a young team, that's just when we're going to be at our best." After going just 3-for-12 on 3-pointers in the first half, the Utes made four of their first seven shots from beyond the arc in the second half to take a 50-37 lead. "They're a great team -- a rhythm team," McKay said. Ricky Johns gave Utah a 39-29 lead with a 3-pointer, Markson followed with another 3 and Luke Nevill converted a three-point play in a 9-2 run that put the Utes up 45-31 with 10:44 remaining. Kellen Walters got the Lobos within 47-34 on two free throws with 9:37 left to play, but Markson answered with his third 3-pointer. The Lobos rallied late in the second half and pulled within 57-46 on Chiotti's 3-pointer with about 4 minutes remaining. But after a time out the Utes got the ball to Markson on the baseline and he leaped for a two-handed dunk to start a 7-2 run that sealed it for Utah. The Utes coasted the rest of the way. "I could see their heads dropping a little bit and that's when I told my team 'It's time to get them right now," Markson said.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
